conclusion: To determine the direction of the acceleration during the 0 to 10 seconds interval, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph provided.
The y-axis represents velocity (v) in meters per second (m/s). The x-axis represents time (t) in seconds (s). The graph shows how the skydiver's velocity changes over time.
From t = 0 to t = 10 seconds, the velocity increases from 0 m/s to 20 m/s.
The slope of the velocity-time graph represents acceleration.
The slope (a) is calculated as the change in velocity (Δv) divided by the change in time (Δt).
a = (v_final - v_initial) / (t_final - t_initial) = (20 m/s - 0 m/s) / (10 s - 0 s) = 2 m/s²
Since the velocity is increasing (going from 0 to 20 m/s), the acceleration is positive.
A positive acceleration in the context of this graph means the direction of acceleration is in the same direction as the velocity, which is downward (since the skydiver is falling).
